question.title: What is a .so file in Java projects, and how can I use an old JAR that depends on .so files in Spring Boot?
question.body:
I have an old Java JAR file that depends on .so files (shared object libraries).

I understand .so files are native libraries (written in C/C++), and the JAR uses JNI (Java Native Interface) or JNA to load them.

In my old project, this JAR worked fine because the .so files were placed in the right location and loaded automatically.

Now, I’m migrating to Spring Boot (3.x, Java 17), and I want to reuse this JAR. My questions are:

  1. What exactly is a .so file in the context of Java? Why is it needed?

  2. How should I include these .so files in a modern Spring Boot application so that the JAR can still use them?

Should they be put in src/main/resources?

Or do I need to set java.library.path at runtime?

Or is there a Spring Boot–specific way of packaging native .so files with my application?

To clarify: the JAR I’m using is an internal project JAR (not a public library), and it relies on some .so files for its functionality. The JAR itself is fixed (I can’t change its code), so I need guidance on the best way to structure or configure the Spring Boot project so it can still load the .so at runtime.
